crs_R45461: The U.S. International Development Finance Corporation (IDFC) is a new government agency that will consolidate the functions of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) and the U.S. Agency for International Development's (USAID) Development Credit Authority (DCA). The IDFC will be responsible for promoting private sector investment in developing countries, with a focus on infrastructure, energy, and other sectors. The agency will also provide political risk insurance and technical assistance to support private investment in developing countries. The IDFC is expected to be operational by the end of 2019.
crs_R44668:
The Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) block grant was created by the 1996 welfare reform law, the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 (P.L. 104-193). The law replaced the Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC) program, which had provided cash assistance to needy families with children since the 1930s. The 1996 law provided both program authority and funding for TANF through the end of FY2002. Since then, extensions have been enacted to extend TANF funding and financing authority. The TANF Extension Act of 2019 (P.L. 116-4) extended TANF funding through June 30, 2019.

The 1996 welfare reform law was the culmination of a debate that had been ongoing for four decades, beginning in the 1960s. The debate focused on the role of work in reducing poverty and the extent to which cash assistance programs should encourage or discourage work. The 1996 law sought to promote work and self-sufficiency by providing a combination of cash assistance, work requirements, and work-related services.

The 1996 law created a new program, TANF, which replaced AFDC. TANF provided cash assistance to needy families with children, but it also required recipients to engage in work activities or participate in work-related activities in order to receive assistance. The law also created a new program, the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC), which provided a refundable tax credit to low-income working families.

The 1996 law also created a new program, the National Child Care Information and Technical Assistance System (NCCITAS), which provided grants to states to help them develop and improve their child care systems. The law also created a new program, the National Family Support Initiative (NFSI), which provided grants to states to help them develop and implement family support programs.

The 1996 law also made significant changes to the Medicaid program, including the creation of the Medicaid Expansion Program (MEP), which provided states with the option to expand Medicaid eligibility to low-income adults who did not have dependent children. The law also created the State Children's Health Insurance Program (SCHIP), which provided grants to states to help them provide health insurance to uninsured children.

The 1996 welfare reform law was a significant change in the way the federal government approached poverty and welfare policy. It sought to promote work and self-sufficiency by providing a combination of cash assistance, work requirements, and work-related services. The law also made significant changes to the Medicaid and child care programs, which aimed to improve the health and well-being of low-income families.
crs_R45546: The Colorado River Basin is a vital resource for agriculture, municipalities, and recreation in the western United States. The river's water is apportioned among the seven states that share its waters through the Colorado River Compact of 1922, which was later modified by the Boulder Canyon Project Act of 1928 and the 1944 U.S.-Mexico Water Treaty. The river's water supply has been affected by climate change, drought, and population growth, leading to increased competition among users and the need for additional water storage and conservation measures.

gao_GAO-19-207: The U.S. Department of Energy's (DOE) Office of Environmental Management (EM) is responsible for cleaning up the nation's nuclear weapons complex, which includes 16 sites with 17,000 structures and 1,000 underground tanks containing radioactive waste. Cleanup at these sites is governed by 72 agreements, including 12 federal facility agreements and 60 state and federal compliance agreements. These agreements include hundreds of milestones that EM must meet to complete the cleanup. gao_GAO-18-486:
The federal-state Unemployment Insurance (UI) program provides temporary cash benefits to eligible workers who lose their jobs through no fault of their own. The program is funded primarily through state payroll taxes on employers and administered by the U.S. Department of Labor (DOL). The federal government provides grants to states to help fund reemployment services and eligibility assessments.

Work search requirements are a key component of the UI program. Federal law requires states to have work search requirements as a condition of eligibility for UI benefits. States have considerable flexibility in determining the specific work search activities that claimants must engage in and the frequency with which they must do so.

DOL uses its Benefit Accuracy Measurement (BAM) system to determine the accuracy of UI payments. BAM involves reviewing a sample of UI claims to determine whether claimants complied with work search requirements and whether the state made improper payments. BAM also helps states identify areas where they can improve their UI programs.

DOL has identified work search overpayments as a significant issue in the UI program. In fiscal year 2017, states made an estimated $1.36 billion in work search overpayments. Factors contributing to this issue include states' inability to verify claimants' work search activities and claimants' failure to comply with work search requirements.

To address work search overpayments, DOL has encouraged states to investigate more claims and to use formal warning systems to inform claimants of their noncompliance with work search requirements. DOL has also provided guidance on how states can improve their work search verification processes.

In summary, the UI program provides temporary cash benefits to eligible workers who lose their jobs through no fault of their own. States have considerable flexibility in determining work search requirements, but work search overpayments remain a significant issue in the program. DOL has encouraged states to investigate more claims and to use formal warning systems to address this issue.
gao_GAO-19-220: The State Department has persistent vacancies in its Foreign Service, with 13% of generalist positions and 14.2% of specialist positions vacant as of March 31, 2018. gao_GAO-19-148: The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) manages and disposes of its real properties through a process that includes identifying underutilized properties, developing disposal plans, and executing disposal actions. gao_GAO-18-271: The U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) agency processes imported goods through a system called ACE (Automated Commercial Environment). gao_GAO-18-78:
The Department of Defense (DOD) has two types of public water systems that provide drinking water to people living and working on military installations. These systems include those that have been treated by DOD and those that have been treated by private companies or local utilities. The DOD is responsible for ensuring that these water systems comply with the Safe Drinking Water Act, which sets standards for drinking water quality.

The Safe Drinking Water Act establishes regulations for contaminants in drinking water, including health-based standards for contaminants such as bacteria, viruses, and chemicals. The DOD is required to report annually to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) on the compliance of its public water systems with these regulations.

The DOD has not consistently reported all violations of the Safe Drinking Water Act to the EPA, as required by DOD policy. In addition, the DOD has not used available data to identify differences in the types of violations between its public water systems that provide DOD-treated water and those that provide non-DOD-treated water.

The DOD has identified 77 military installations with at least one violation of the Safe Drinking Water Act during the period of 2013-2015. The most common types of violations were for bacteria and disinfection byproducts.

The DOD has taken steps to address these issues, including developing a plan to improve the reporting of Safe Drinking Water Act violations and conducting a study to identify differences in violations between DOD-treated and non-DOD-treated water systems.
gao_GAO-18-420: The federal government owns and operates a vast inventory of buildings, which are expensive to maintain and operate. gao_GAO-18-249: The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) is a government agency that reviews foreign investments in the United States to ensure they do not pose a threat to national security. The agency reviews transactions involving a foreign person's acquisition of a U.S. business, real estate, or other assets. CFIUS has the authority to suspend or prohibit a transaction if it poses a threat to national security. The agency's review process includes four stages: pre-notice consultation, national security review, national security investigation, and presidential action. CFIUS has been increasingly active in recent years, leading to concerns from stakeholders about the agency's workload and the need for additional staffing.
gao_GAO-18-7: The National Strategy for Combating Wildlife Trafficking and Reducing Demand aims to reduce demand for illegally traded wildlife by raising public awareness of the harms caused by wildlife trafficking and changing harmful consumption patterns.
